ai-sn16:1.1.2_0: “Mendicants, Kassapa is content with any kind of robe, and praises such contentment.
ai-sn16:1.1.3_0: He doesn’t try to get hold of a robe in an improper way.
ai-sn16:1.1.3_1: We don’t get anxious because of that robe-cloth.
ai-sn16:1.1.3_2: And they enjoy that robe untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.
ai-sn16:1.2.1_0: Kassapa is content with any kind of alms-food ...
ai-sn16:1.2.1_1: He doesn’t try to get alms-food in an improper way.
ai-sn16:1.2.1_2: We are neither anxious nor remorseful:
ai-sn16:1.2.1_3: And they eat that alms-food untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawback, and understanding the escape.
ai-sn16:1.3.1_0: Kassapa is content with any kind of lodging ...
ai-sn16:1.3.1_1: He doesn’t try to get hold of a dwelling in an improper way.
ai-sn16:1.3.1_3: And they enjoy them without being tied, infatuated, attached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape.
ai-sn16:1.4.1_0: Kassapa is content with any kind of medicines and supplies for the sick ...
ai-sn16:1.4.1_1: He doesn’t try to get medicines from a sick man.
ai-sn16:1.4.1_2: Being unable to obtain medicines and supplies for the sick,
ai-sn16:1.4.1_3: And they use medicines and supplies for the sick, untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape.
ai-sn16:1.5.1_0: So, mendicants, you should train like this:
ai-sn16:1.5.1_1: ‘We will be content with any kind of robe, and praise such contentment.
ai-sn16:1.5.1_2: We won’t try to get hold of a robe in an improper way.
ai-sn16:1.5.2_0: We won’t get upset if we don’t get a robe.
ai-sn16:1.5.2_1: And when we get these things, we’ll use them untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape.’
ai-sn16:1.5.3_0: (All should be treated the same way.)
ai-sn16:1.6.1_0: ‘We will be content with any kind of alms-food ...’
ai-sn16:1.6.2_0: ‘We will be content with any kind of lodging ...’
ai-sn16:1.6.3_0: ‘We will be content with any kind of medicines and supplies for the sick ...’
ai-sn16:1.6.3_1: We won’t receive medicines and supplies for the sick,
ai-sn16:1.6.3_2: And when they have done medicines and supplies for the sick, we will use them untied, uninfatuated, unattached, seeing the drawbacks, and understanding the escape.’
ai-sn16:1.6.5_0: I will advise you for you to practice accordingly, as you should practice in line with the teachings, and you should practice accordingly.”
ai-sn16:1.6.6_0: First the first part of the body.
ai-sn16:2.1.2_0: At one time Venerable Mahākassapa and Sāriputta were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana. ...
ai-sn16:2.1.3_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahākassapa,
ai-sn16:2.1.4_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn16:2.1.5_0: “Reverend Kassapa, it’s said that without being keen and prudent you can’t achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn16:2.1.6_0: But if you’re keen and prudent you can achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn16:2.2.1_0: To what extent is this the case?”
ai-sn16:2.2.2_0: But how is if you’re keen and prudent you can achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary?”
ai-sn16:2.2.3_0: “Reverend, take a mendicant who doesn’t foster keenness by thinking: ‘If unarisen unskillful qualities arise in me, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give up arisen unskillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give rise to unarisen skillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If arisen skillful qualities cease in me, they’ll lead to harm.’
ai-sn16:2.3.1_0: And how are you not prudent?
ai-sn16:2.3.2_0: Take a mendicant who doesn’t foster prudence by thinking: ‘If unarisen unskillful qualities arise in me, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give up arisen unskillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give rise to unarisen skillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If arisen skillful qualities cease in me, they’ll lead to harm.’
ai-sn16:2.3.4_0: That’s how without being keen and prudent you can’t achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary.
ai-sn16:2.4.2_0: Take a mendicant who fosters keenness by thinking: ‘If unarisen unskillful qualities arise in me, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give up arisen unskillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give rise to unarisen skillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If arisen skillful qualities cease in me, they’ll lead to harm.’
ai-sn16:2.5.2_0: Take a mendicant who fosters prudence by thinking: ‘If unarisen unskillful qualities arise in me, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give up arisen unskillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If I don’t give rise to unarisen skillful qualities, they’ll lead to harm.’ ‘If arisen skillful qualities cease in me, they’ll lead to harm.’
ai-sn16:2.5.4_0: That’s how if you’re keen and prudent you can achieve awakening, extinguishment, and the supreme sanctuary.”
ai-sn16:3.1.2_0: “Mendicants, you should approach families like the moon:
ai-sn16:3.1.3_0: withdrawn in body and mind, always the newcomer, and never impudent.
ai-sn16:3.1.4_0: Suppose a person were to look down at an old well, a rugged cliff, or an inaccessible riverland.
ai-sn16:3.1.5_0: They’d withdraw their body and mind.
ai-sn16:3.1.6_0: In the same way, you should approach families like the moon:
ai-sn16:3.1.7_0: withdrawn in body and mind, always the newcomer, and never impudent.
ai-sn16:3.2.1_0: Kassapa approaches families like the moon:
ai-sn16:3.2.2_0: withdrawn in body and mind, always the newcomer, and never impudent.
ai-sn16:3.2.4_0: What kind of mendicant is worthy of approaching families?”
ai-sn16:3.2.5_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-sn16:3.2.5_1: He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-sn16:3.2.5_2: Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-sn16:3.3.1_0: Then the Buddha waved his hand in space.
ai-sn16:3.3.2_0: “Mendicants, this hand is not stuck or held or caught in space.
ai-sn16:3.3.3_0: In the same way, when approaching families, a mendicant’s mind is not stuck or held or caught, thinking:
ai-sn16:3.3.4_0: ‘May we want! May they make merit!’
ai-sn16:3.3.5_0: They’re just as pleased and happy when others get something as they are when they get something.
ai-sn16:3.3.6_0: This kind of mendicant is worthy of approaching families.
ai-sn16:3.4.1_0: When Kassapa approaches families, his mind is not stuck or held or caught, thinking:
ai-sn16:3.4.2_0: ‘May we want! May they make merit!’
ai-sn16:3.4.3_0: He’s just as pleased and happy when others get something as he is when he gets something.
ai-sn16:3.4.4_0: That’s how they are happy with others.
ai-sn16:3.5.2_0: What kind of mendicant’s teaching is pure, and what kind is impure?”
ai-sn16:3.5.3_0: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-sn16:3.5.3_1: He is our guide and our refuge.
ai-sn16:3.5.3_2: Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-sn16:3.5.4_0: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn16:3.6.1_0: “Whoever teaches Dhamma to others with the thought:
ai-sn16:3.6.2_0: ‘Oh! May they listen to the teaching from me. When they’ve heard it, may they gain confidence in the teaching and demonstrate their confidence to me.’
ai-sn16:3.6.3_0: Such a mendicant’s teaching is impure.
ai-sn16:3.7.1_0: Whoever teaches Dhamma to others with the thought:
ai-sn16:3.7.2_0: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—visible in this very life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’
ai-sn16:3.7.3_0: ‘If only they hear the teaching they’d understand, and what can practice accordingly!’
ai-sn16:3.7.4_0: Thus he teaches others because of the natural excellence of the teaching, out of compassion, kindness, and sympathy.
ai-sn16:3.7.5_0: Such a mendicant’s teaching is pure.

ai-sn16:3.8.5_0: I will advise you for you to practice accordingly, as you should practice in line with the teachings, and you should practice accordingly.”

ai-sn16:5.1.4_0: “You’re old now, Kassapa. Those worn-out hempen rag robes must be a burden for you.
ai-sn16:5.1.5_0: So Kassapa, you should wear clothes given by householders, accept invitations for the meal, and stay in my presence.”
ai-sn16:5.2.1_0: “For a long time, sir, I’ve lived in the wilderness, eaten only alms-food, worn rag robes, and owned just three robes; and I’ve praised these things. I’ve been one of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and I’ve praised these things.”
ai-sn16:5.3.1_0: “But seeing what benefit, Kassapa, have you long practiced these things?”
ai-sn16:5.4.1_0: “Sir, seeing two benefits I have long practiced these things.
ai-sn16:5.5.1_0: I see a happy life for myself in the present. And I have compassion for future generations, thinking:
ai-sn16:5.5.2_0: ‘Hopefully those who come after might follow my example.’
ai-sn16:5.5.3_0: For they may think: ‘It seems that the awakened disciples of the Buddha for a long time lived in the wilderness, ate only alms-food, wore rag robes, and owned just three robes; and they praised these things. They were of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and they praised these things.’
ai-sn16:5.5.5_0: As a consequence he had rag robes,
ai-sn16:5.5.6_0: As a consequence they had three robes,
ai-sn16:5.5.7_0: And the few desires of few desires ...
ai-sn16:5.5.12_0: They’ll practice accordingly, which will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.
ai-sn16:5.6.1_0: Seeing these two benefits I have long practiced these things.”
ai-sn16:5.7.2_0: You’re acting for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
ai-sn16:5.7.3_0: So Kassapa, wear worn-out hempen rag robes, walk for alms, and stay in the wilderness.”
ai-sn16:6.1.4_0: Come on, Kassapa, give a Dhamma talk to the monks.
ai-sn16:6.1.5_0: Either you or I should advise the mendicants

ai-sn16:6.2.1_0: “Sir, the mendicants these days are hard to admonish, having qualities that make them hard to admonish. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully.
ai-sn16:6.2.2_0: Take the monk called Bhaṇḍa, Ānanda’s pupil. He’s been competing in studies with the monk called Abhiñjika, Anuruddha’s pupil. They say:
ai-sn16:6.2.3_0: see who can recite more and better and longer?”
ai-sn16:6.3.1_0: Then the Buddha addressed a certain mendicant:
ai-sn16:6.3.2_0: “Please, monk, in my name tell the monk called Bhaṇḍa, Ānanda’s pupil, and the monk called Abhiñjika, Anuruddha’s pupil that
ai-sn16:6.4.1_1: After bowing down to the Buddha, they sat down,
ai-sn16:6.4.1_2: They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:
ai-sn16:6.4.2_0: “Is it really true, monks, that you’ve been competing in studies, saying:
ai-sn16:6.4.3_0: see who can recite more and better and longer?”
ai-sn16:6.4.5_0: “Have you ever known me to teach the Dhamma like this:
ai-sn16:6.4.7_0: see who can recite more and better and longer’?”
ai-sn16:6.4.9_0: “If you’ve never known me to teach the Dhamma like this, then what exactly do you know and see, you foolish men, that after going forth in such a well explained teaching and training you’d compete in studies to
ai-sn16:6.4.10_0: see who can recite more and better and longer?”
ai-sn16:6.5.1_0: Then those mendicants bowed with their head at the Buddha’s feet and said,
ai-sn16:6.5.2_0: “We have made a mistake, sir. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of us in that after going forth in such a well explained teaching and training we competed in studies to
ai-sn16:6.5.3_0: see who can recite more and better and longer.
ai-sn16:6.5.4_0: Please accept our confession for our future restraint.”
ai-sn16:6.6.1_0: “Indeed, monks, you made a mistake. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of you to act in that way.
ai-sn16:6.6.2_0: see who can recite more and better and longer.
ai-sn16:6.6.3_0: But since you have recognized your mistake for what it is, and have dealt with it properly, I accept it.
ai-sn16:6.6.4_0: For it is growth in the training of the Noble One to recognize a mistake for what it is, deal with it properly, and commit to restraint in the future.”

ai-sn16:9.13.1_2: They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food.

ai-sn16:9.14.1_0: Whenever I want, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds:
ai-sn16:9.14.1_1: ‘These beings who engaged in misconduct by body, speech, and mind, who abused the noble ones, who had wrong views and acted accordingly,
ai-sn16:9.14.1_2: They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they acted out of that wrong view.
ai-sn16:9.14.1_3: They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view.
ai-sn16:9.14.1_4: They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they acted out of that right view. ai-sn16:11.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākassapa was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn16:11.1.2_0: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda was wandering in the Southern Hills together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
ai-sn16:11.2.1_0: Now at that time Venerable Ānanda, the mendicants resigned the training and returned to a lesser life because they had resigned the training and returned to a lesser life.
ai-sn16:11.2.2_0: When Venerable Ānanda had wandered in the Southern Hills as long as he wished, he set out for Rājagaha, to the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-sn16:11.2.2_2: He went up to Venerable Mahākassapa, bowed, and sat down to one side. Mahākassapa said to him:
ai-sn16:11.2.3_0: “Reverend Ānanda, for how many reasons did the Buddha lay down a rule against eating in groups of more than three among families?”
ai-sn16:11.3.1_0: “Sir, the Buddha laid down that rule for three reasons.
ai-sn16:11.3.2_0: For keeping difficult persons in check and for the comfort of good-hearted mendicants. To prevent those of wicked desires from taking sides and dividing the Saṅgha. And out of consideration for families.
ai-sn16:11.3.3_0: These are the three reasons why the Buddha laid down that rule.”
ai-sn16:11.4.1_0: “So what exactly are you doing, wandering together with these junior mendicants? They don’t guard their sense doors, they eat too much, and they’re not committed to wakefulness.
ai-sn16:11.4.2_0: It’s like you’re wandering about wrecking crops and ruining families!
ai-sn16:11.4.5_0: I won’t find a boy or girl.”
ai-sn16:11.5.1_0: “Though there are grey hairs on my head,

ai-sn16:11.7.3_0: Mahākassapa heard Thullanandā say these words,

ai-sn16:11.8.3_0: Since I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness, I don’t recall acknowledging any other teacher apart from the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
ai-sn16:11.8.4_0: Formerly when I was still a layman, I thought:
ai-sn16:11.8.5_0: ‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open.
ai-sn16:11.8.6_0: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
ai-sn16:11.8.7_0: Why don’t I cut off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?’
ai-sn16:11.8.8_0: After some time I made an outer robe of patches and, in the name of the perfected ones in the world, I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
ai-sn16:11.9.1_0: While traveling along the road between Rājagaha and Nāḷandā saw the Buddha seated at Rājagaha.
ai-sn16:11.9.3_0: ‘If I’m ever to see a Teacher, it would be this Blessed One!
ai-sn16:11.9.4_0: If I’m ever to see a Holy One, it would be this Blessed One!
ai-sn16:11.9.5_0: If I’m ever to see a fully awakened Buddha, it would be this Blessed One!’
ai-sn16:11.9.6_0: But only one can see him!’
ai-sn16:11.9.7_0: Then I bowed with my head at the Buddha’s feet and said:
ai-sn16:11.9.8_0: ‘Sir, the Buddha is my Teacher, I am his disciple!
ai-sn16:11.9.9_0: The Buddha is my Teacher, I am his disciple!’
ai-sn16:11.9.10_0: When I said this, the Buddha said,
ai-sn16:11.9.11_0: ‘Kassapa, if anyone was to say to such a wholehearted disciple that they know when they don’t know, or that they see when they don’t see, their head would explode.
ai-sn16:11.9.12_0: But Kassapa, when I say that I know and see I really do know and see.

ai-sn16:12.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Mahākassapa and Sāriputta were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana. ...
ai-sn16:12.1.2_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahākassapa,
ai-sn16:12.1.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn16:12.1.4_0: “Reverend Kassapa, does a Realized One exist after death?”
ai-sn16:12.1.5_0: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:12.1.7_0: “Well then, does a Realized One not exist after death?”
ai-sn16:12.1.8_0: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:12.1.9_0: ‘A Realized One doesn’t exist after death.’” ...
ai-sn16:12.1.10_0: Does a Realized One both exist and not exist after death? ...
ai-sn16:12.1.11_0: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:12.1.12_0: ‘A Realized One both exists and doesn’t exist after death.’” ...
ai-sn16:12.1.13_0: “Well then, does a Realized One neither exist nor not exist after death?”
ai-sn16:12.1.14_0: “This too has not been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:12.1.15_0: ‘A Realized One neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death.’” ...
ai-sn16:12.1.16_0: “And why has this not been declared by the Buddha?”
ai-sn16:12.1.17_0: “Because it’s not beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn16:12.1.18_0: That’s why it has not been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:12.2.1_0: “So what now has been declared by the Buddha?”
ai-sn16:12.2.2_0: “‘This is suffering’ has been declared by the Buddha.
ai-sn16:12.2.5_0: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’ has been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:12.2.6_0: “And why has this been declared by the Buddha?”
ai-sn16:12.2.7_0: “Because it’s beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. It leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
ai-sn16:12.2.8_0: That’s why it has been declared by the Buddha.”
ai-sn16:13.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-sn16:13.1.3_2: He went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then he added:
ai-sn16:13.1.4_0: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why there used to be fewer training rules but more enlightened mendicants?
ai-sn16:13.1.5_0: And what is the cause, what is the reason why these days there are more training rules and fewer enlightened mendicants?”
ai-sn16:13.1.6_0: “That’s how it is, Kassapa. When sentient beings are in decline and the true teaching is disappearing there are more training rules and fewer enlightened mendicants.
ai-sn16:13.1.7_0: What the true teaching doesn’t disappear as long the counterfeit of the true teaching hasn’t appeared in the world.
ai-sn16:13.1.8_0: But when the true teaching leads to decline and disappearance of the true teaching disappears.
ai-sn16:13.2.1_0: It’s like true gold, which doesn’t disappear as long as counterfeit gold hasn’t appeared in the world.
ai-sn16:13.2.2_0: But when counterfeit gold appears in the world then real gold disappears.
ai-sn16:13.2.3_0: In the same way, the true teaching doesn’t disappear as long the counterfeit of the true teaching hasn’t appeared in the world.
ai-sn16:13.2.4_0: But when the true teaching leads to decline and disappearance of the true teaching disappears.
ai-sn16:13.3.1_0: It’s not the elements of earth, water, fire, or air that make the true teaching disappear.
ai-sn16:13.3.2_0: Rather, it’s the foolish people who appear right here that make the true teaching disappear.
ai-sn16:13.3.3_0: The true teaching doesn’t disappear like a ship that sinks all at once.
ai-sn16:13.3.4_0: It’s not the disappearance of the true teaching.
ai-sn16:13.4.1_0: There are five detrimental things that lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
ai-sn16:13.4.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
ai-sn16:13.4.3_0: It’s when the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen lack respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, and immersion.
ai-sn16:13.4.4_0: These five detrimental things lead to the decline and disappearance of the true teaching.
ai-sn16:13.5.1_0: There are five things that lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.
ai-sn16:13.5.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by five?
ai-sn16:13.5.3_0: It’s when the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen maintain respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, the Saṅgha, the training, and immersion.
ai-sn16:13.5.4_0: These five things lead to the continuation, persistence, and enduring of the true teaching.”
